U Španiji osuda plakata na kojima su katalonski novinari nazvani 'teroristima'

06 Nov 2019, 21:50












Plakati danas izlepljeni u Barseloni na kojima autori katalonske novinare nazivaju "teroristima", oštro su osudjeni u Španiji, a osudi se priključio i šef vlade Pedro Sančes.Plakati, s tekstom na katalonskom, usmrenei su protiv šest novinara, od kojih dva rade za državnu TV, "ubice u službi vlasti" i "informativni teroristi koji opslužuju Ibeks"-  berzanski indeks velikih španskih kompanija, a na plakatima je i poziv da "ostanu u Madridu". Šef Vlade, Sančes, izjavio je da "snažno osudjuje te pretnje" i da "podržava katalonske novinare koji su meta". Lider desničarske opozicije Pablo Kasado osudio je "nepodnošljivo zastrašivanje". U zajedničkoj izjavi, Savez novinarskih udruženja Španije i Madridsko udruženje za štampu izrazili su oštru osudu i ukazali da "tolikog nasilja i neprijateljstva prema štampi nikada do danas nije bilo u Kataloniji".Plakati su se pojavili u vreme napetosti u Kataloniji posle sudskog kažnjavanja 14. oktobra lidera pokreta za nezavisnost teškim zatvorskim kaznama zbog pokušaja otcepljenja od Španije 2017. godine.Te presude su izazvale demonstracije, od kojih su neke prerasle u nasilne sukobe s policijom.Tokom tih dogadjaja separatistički aktivisti i demonstranti su španske novinare sprečavali da rade i dovikivali im da su "manipulatori španske štampe!". S druge strane, novinari bliski pokretu za nezavisnost Katalonije su bili žrtve agresije tokom manifestacija za jedinstvo Španije.

In Spain, condemnation of posters calling Catalan journalists 'terrorists'

06 Nov 2019, 20:50












Posters made today in Barcelona, dubbed "terrorists" by Catalan journalists, have been sharply condemned in Spain, and Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has joined in. The posters, with a Catalan text, are directed against six journalists, two of whom work for the state TV, "killers in the service of government" and "information terrorists serving Ibeks" - a stock exchange index of large Spanish companies, with a poster calling for "stay in Madrid". The head of government, Sanchez, said he "strongly condemned these threats" and "supported the target Catalan journalists." Right-wing opposition leader Pablo Kasado denounced the "unbearable intimidation". In a joint statement, the Union of Journalists of Spain and the Madrid Press Association expressed strong condemnation, pointing out that "so much violence and hostility to the press has never been in Catalonia to this day." Posters emerged during a tensions in Catalonia after sentencing 14. October leaders of the Independence Movement heavy prison sentences for trying to secede from Spain in 2017.These verdicts sparked demonstrations, some of which turned into violent clashes with police.During these events, separatist activists and protesters prevented Spanish journalists from working and calling for them that they are "manipulators of the Spanish press!". Journalists close to the Catalonia independence movement, on the other hand, were victims of aggression during events for Spain's unity.
